linear-graphs-node-1.title: Plotting Points on Cartesian Plane
learningFocus: Plotting points in all four quadrants

exemplarProblems.problemText: Plot the point (-3, 4) on the Cartesian plane. In which quadrant does this point lie?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Quadrant II (x is negative, y is positive)

exemplarProblems.problemText: The point P lies at coordinates (2, -5). State which quadrant P is in.

questionTypes: Given quadrant, identify which points could lie there

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem. Maximum TWO questions ONLY if the second depends on the first
Use integer coordinates between -6 and 6
Vary quadrants across different problems
Include origin (0,0) occasionally
Test understanding of negative coordinates
DO NOT include mathTool - plotting is the exercise itself

linear-graphs-node-2.title: Identifying Linear Relationships

exemplarProblems.problemText: A table shows x values: 0, 1, 2, 3 and y values: 2, 5, 8, 11. Is this a linear relationship? Explain your reasoning.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Yes, it is linear. The y-values increase by 3 each time (constant rate of change: +3)

exemplarProblems.problemText: For the values x: 1, 2, 3, 4 and y: 1, 4, 9, 16, determine if the relationship is linear.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: No, not linear. The differences are +3, +5, +7 (not constant). This is quadratic (y = x²)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Present data as a table of x and y values
Mix linear and non-linear examples
For linear: ensure constant differences
For non-linear: use simple patterns (quadratic or exponential)
Ask students to explain their reasoning
DO NOT include mathTool - checking calculations is the exercise

linear-graphs-node-3.title: Understanding Gradient as Rise over Run

exemplarProblems.problemText: A line rises 6 units for every 2 units it moves horizontally. Calculate the gradient.
Between two points, a line goes up 12 units while moving 4 units to the right. What is its gradient?

contexts: rises X units for every Y units horizontally
goes up X while moving Y to the right
vertical change of X, horizontal change of Y

parameters.caption: The line shows rise and run between two points

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool when asking to identify rise/run from a graph
OMIT mathTool when asking to calculate gradient from given rise/run values (would show answer)
Use simple whole number gradients initially
Ensure rise and run values create recognizable gradients
For mathTool: use showPoints to mark two clear points on the line
Caption should prompt students to count rise and run on the grid

linear-graphs-node-4.title: Calculating Gradient from Two Points

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find the gradient of the line passing through points (1, 3) and (5, 11).
Calculate the gradient between (-2, 5) and (4, -1).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Use clear integer coordinates
Include both positive and negative gradients
Vary whether coordinates are positive, negative, or mixed
Simplify fractions where possible
DO NOT include mathTool - calculation practice is the goal

linear-graphs-node-5.title: Positive, Negative, Zero, and Undefined Gradients

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find the gradient of the line through (2, 5) and (6, 13). Is it positive, negative, zero, or undefined?
Calculate the gradient between points (3, 7) and (3, -2). What type of gradient is this?
What is the gradient of the line passing through (-1, 4) and (5, 4)?

parameters.caption: This line has a negative gradient (slopes downward)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool to show visual examples of different gradient types (context only, not revealing calculation)
OMIT mathTool when asking students to calculate and classify (would give answer visually)
Cover all four types: positive, negative, zero, undefined
For vertical lines: ensure x-coordinates are identical
For horizontal lines: ensure y-coordinates are identical
Ask students to both calculate AND classify the gradient type

linear-graphs-node-6.title: Finding and Understanding y-intercept
learningFocus: y-intercept is where line crosses y-axis
Reading y-intercept from graphs and equations

exemplarProblems.problemText: From the equation y = 3x + 5, identify the y-intercept.
A line has gradient 2 and passes through the point (3, 11). Find the y-intercept.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Using y = mx + c: 11 = 2(3) + c, so 11 = 6 + c, therefore c = 5

parameters.caption: The y-intercept is where the line crosses the y-axis

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool when asking to identify y-intercept from a graph (visual reading exercise)
OMIT mathTool when asking to calculate y-intercept from equation or point+gradient (would show answer)
For mathTool: use showPoints to highlight the y-intercept
When finding c from point and gradient, provide clear coordinates
Include equations in y = mx + c form
Test both reading from equations and calculating from points

linear-graphs-node-7.title: Connecting Gradient and y-intercept
learningFocus: Both m and c define a unique line
Parallel lines: same m, different c

exemplarProblems.problemText: A line has equation y = -2x + 7. State the gradient and y-intercept.
Two lines are parallel. One has equation y = 3x + 2. If the other line has y-intercept 5, what is its equation?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool when showing relationship between m and c visually
Ask students to identify BOTH gradient and y-intercept
Test understanding of parallel lines (same m)
Include questions about completing partial equations
For mathTool: use showPoints to highlight both features clearly

linear-graphs-node-8.title: Reading and Writing y = mx + c Equations
learningFocus: Identifying m and c from equations
Writing equations given m and c

exemplarProblems.problemText: Write the equation of a line with gradient 3 and y-intercept -2.
From the equation y = -4x + 7, identify the gradient.
Write the equation: gradient -0.5, y-intercept 6.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Test both directions: reading from equations and writing equations
Handle special cases: c = 0, m = 1, m = -1
Use proper notation: y = 2x - 3 (not y = 2x + -3)
Include fractional gradients occasionally
DO NOT include mathTool - algebraic manipulation is the focus

linear-graphs-node-9.title: Writing Equations from Graphs
learningFocus: Calculating gradient using two points on graph
Combining to write y = mx + c

exemplarProblems.problemText: A line crosses the y-axis at (0, 2) and passes through (3, 8). Write its equation.
From the graph showing y-intercept -1 and passing through (2, 5), find the equation.

parameters.caption: Use the graph to find the gradient and y-intercept

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool showing the line with clear points marked
For mathTool: Always show (0, c) and one other clear point
Ensure points land on grid intersections
Students should read c directly and calculate m
Caption should prompt to identify both m and c

linear-graphs-node-10.title: Real-World Linear Equations
learningFocus: Gradient as rate of change in context
y-intercept as initial value or fixed cost

exemplarProblems.problemText: A phone plan costs \$25 per month plus \$0.10 per minute of calls. Write an equation for total cost C in terms of minutes m.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: C = 0.10m + 25 (gradient = \$0.10 per minute, y-intercept = \$25 base fee)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A water tank contains 400 litres and drains at 15 litres per hour. Write an equation for water W after h hours.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Use realistic contexts familiar to students
Clearly state what m represents (rate) and c represents (initial/fixed)
Include both increasing (positive m) and decreasing (negative m) situations
Use appropriate units (dollars, litres, kilometres, etc.)
For currency, use escaped dollar: \$25 (NOT $25$ which is LaTeX)
DO NOT include mathTool - word problem interpretation is the goal

linear-graphs-node-11.title: Finding Equation from Two Points
learningFocus: Two-step method: find m, then find c
Substituting point into y = mx + c to find c

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find the equation of the line passing through (1, 5) and (4, 14).
A line passes through (-2, 8) and (3, -2). What is its equation?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Use integer coordinates that yield clean gradients
Include both positive and negative gradients
Mix positive, negative, and zero y-intercepts
Vary whether points are in positive or negative regions
DO NOT include mathTool - algebraic method practice is the goal

linear-graphs-node-12.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
learningFocus: Parallel lines have equal gradients (m₁ = m₂)
Finding equation of parallel line through given point

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find the equation of the line parallel to y = 2x + 3 that passes through (1, 7).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Parallel means same gradient: m = 2. Using (1,7): 7 = 2(1) + c, so c = 5. Equation: y = 2x + 5

exemplarProblems.problemText: A line is parallel to y = -3x + 1 and has y-intercept 4. Write its equation.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Same gradient m = -3, given c = 4, so y = -3x + 4

parameters.label: y = 2x + 1
parameters.caption: A parallel line would have the same gradient (m = 2) but different y-intercept

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool to show the original line (parallel line not drawn - student finds it)
Emphasize that parallel means same gradient
Test both: finding equation given point, and given y-intercept
For perpendicular (extension): mention m₁ × m₂ = -1
Use clear integer gradients

linear-graphs-node-13.title: Creating Table of Values

exemplarProblems.problemText: Create a table of values for y = 2x + 1 using x-values: -1, 0, 1, 2, 3.
For the equation y = -3x + 4, find the y-values when x = 0, 1, 2.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Always include x = 0 in the table (easy to check y-intercept)
Use integer x-values between -3 and 4
Provide the equation and x-values; students calculate y
Use equations that yield integer y-values at given x-points
DO NOT include mathTool - table creation is the exercise itself

linear-graphs-node-14.title: Graphing Using Gradient and y-intercept
learningFocus: Use rise/run from gradient to find next point

exemplarProblems.problemText: Graph y = 3x + 2 using the gradient-intercept method. Describe your steps.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Step 1: Plot y-intercept (0, 2). Step 2: Gradient 3 = 3/1, so from (0,2) go right 1, up 3 to (1, 5). Step 3: Draw line through points.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Using gradient and y-intercept, explain how to graph y = -2x + 5.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Start at (0, 5). Gradient -2 = -2/1: go right 1, down 2 to (1, 3). Draw line.

parameters.caption: From y-intercept (0,1), use gradient m=2 to find (1,3)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool to demonstrate the method (showing completed graph as reference)
For questions asking students to graph: OMIT mathTool (would show answer)
Use gradients that are easy to visualize (whole numbers or simple fractions)
Caption should explain the rise/run movement
Test understanding of negative gradients (move down)

linear-graphs-node-15.title: Horizontal and Vertical Lines

exemplarProblems.problemText: Write the equation of the horizontal line passing through the point (5, 3).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: y = 3 (all points on this line have y-coordinate 3)

exemplarProblems.problemText: What is the equation of the vertical line through (-2, 7)?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: x = -2 (all points on this line have x-coordinate -2)

exemplarProblems.problemText: State the gradient of the line y = 5.

parameters.caption: All points have y = 2. This is the horizontal line y = 2

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool to show examples of horizontal/vertical lines with multiple points marked
For horizontal line y = c: mark points with same y-coordinate
For vertical line x = a: mark points with same x-coordinate
Test both writing equations and identifying gradient type
Remind students: y = [number] is HORIZONTAL, x = [number] is VERTICAL

linear-graphs-node-16.title: Understanding Simultaneous Equations

exemplarProblems.problemText: Verify whether the point (2, 3) is a solution to the system: x + y = 5 and 2x - y = 1.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Eq1: 2 + 3 = 5 ✓. Eq2: 2(2) - 3 = 4 - 3 = 1 ✓. Yes, (2, 3) satisfies both equations.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Check if (1, 4) is the solution to: 3x + y = 7 and x - y = -3.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Eq1: 3(1) + 4 = 3 + 4 = 7 ✓. Eq2: 1 - 4 = -3 ✓. Yes, it is the solution.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Provide the system and a point to verify
Include both valid solutions and non-solutions
Ask students to show substitution work for both equations
Use simple integer coefficients
DO NOT include mathTool - verification by substitution is the exercise

linear-graphs-node-17.title: Solving Graphically
learningFocus: Graph both equations on same axes

exemplarProblems.problemText: From the graph showing lines y = x + 1 and y = -x + 5 intersecting at (2, 3), state the solution to the simultaneous equations.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: x = 2, y = 3 (the coordinates of the intersection point)

exemplarProblems.problemText: Two lines 2x + y = 8 and x - y = 1 are graphed. They intersect at (3, 2). Verify this is the solution.

parameters.caption: The lines intersect at (2, 3), which is the solution

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool to show graphical solution method
For simultaneousEquationsSolver: use format {a, b, c} for ax + by = c
Intersection should be at integer coordinates for easy reading
Ask students to identify solution from graph OR verify given solution
Caption should explain that intersection = solution

linear-graphs-node-18.title: Substitution Method
learningFocus: Express one variable in terms of the other
Solve for one variable, then back-substitute

exemplarProblems.problemText: Solve using substitution: y = 2x + 1 and x + y = 7.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Substitute y = 2x + 1 into x + y = 7: x + (2x + 1) = 7, so 3x = 6, x = 2. Then y = 2(2) + 1 = 5. Solution: x = 2, y = 5

exemplarProblems.problemText: Use substitution to solve: 2x + y = 11 and y = 3x + 1.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Substitute y = 3x + 1 into 2x + y = 11: 2x + (3x + 1) = 11, so 5x = 10, x = 2. Then y = 3(2) + 1 = 7. Solution: x = 2, y = 7

parameters.caption: Substitution method: Express y from Eq1, substitute into Eq2

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool with showSteps: true to demonstrate method
One equation should have a variable already isolated (y = ... or x = ...)
Use simple coefficients that lead to integer solutions
Ask students to show all substitution steps
For simultaneousEquationsSolver: convert y = mx + c to ax + by = c format (e.g., y = 2x + 1 becomes -2x + y = 1)

linear-graphs-node-19.title: Elimination Method
learningFocus: Adding or subtracting equations to eliminate variable

exemplarProblems.problemText: Solve using elimination: 3x + 2y = 16 and 3x - y = 7.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Subtract equations: (3x + 2y) - (3x - y) = 16 - 7, so 3y = 9, y = 3. Substitute into first: 3x + 2(3) = 16, so 3x = 10, x = 10/3. Solution: x = 10/3, y = 3

exemplarProblems.problemText: Use elimination: 2x + 3y = 13 and x + y = 5.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Multiply second by 2: 2x + 2y = 10. Subtract from first: (2x + 3y) - (2x + 2y) = 13 - 10, so y = 3. Then x + 3 = 5, x = 2. Solution: x = 2, y = 3

parameters.caption: Elimination method: Coefficients of x already match, subtract equations

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool with showSteps: true for demonstration
Mix cases: some with matching coefficients, some requiring multiplication
When coefficients match: decide if add or subtract based on signs
Use integer coefficients and solutions
For simultaneousEquationsSolver: use {a, b, c} format for ax + by = c

linear-graphs-node-20.title: Choosing the Best Method

exemplarProblems.problemText: For the system y = 3x - 2 and 2x + y = 8, which algebraic method would be most efficient: substitution or elimination? Explain why.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Substitution is most efficient because y is already isolated in the first equation

exemplarProblems.problemText: For the system 4x + 3y = 18 and 4x - y = 6, which method is most efficient?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Elimination is most efficient because the coefficients of x already match (both are 4)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Present a system and ask which method is best
Include clear indicators: isolated variable → substitution, matching coefficients → elimination
Ask students to explain their reasoning
Optionally: ask them to solve using their chosen method
DO NOT include mathTool - strategic thinking is the focus
